documents.title: a view from a parent of two
text: we got in an interesting comment via our form from a 32-year-old parent of two children , based in scotland .
they offer a hopeful of how to engage kids in healthy eating : all our main meals are cooked with fresh ingredients so we know what 's going in .
kids are involved in the cooking ( and growing food ) so they learn to enjoy food .
sweet/sugary treats are not forbidden but are limited , usually as a treat with lunch or after school on a friday .
my kids are young enough that i do n't have to worry about them eating junk food unless we give them it , they do n't get fizzy juice and the diluting juice they do get is sugar free .
we do n't eat takeaways or prepacked food .
biggest issue is breakfast cereals , even wheetabix has added sugar these days !
they also talked about a great initiative their school is involved in : our school does a wednesday wander where all the kids ( preschool to p7 ) all walk , run , skip etc a mile every wednesday .
the kids love it !
all the schools in the local area grow their own fruit and veg and do basic cooking with the ingredients they 've grown .
we also have a new community growing area that 's trying to get families out growing and cooking their own food .
that 's something to be hopeful for and a nice note to end on .

documents.title: should we focus on exercise over sugar taxes ?
text: ovilier 18 august 2016 1:53pm i think too much damage has already been done for a sugar tax to be effective now , so many people are just too used to eating sugary food for almost every meal of the day , it 's pretty addictive stuff and i think most people will just respond angrily to a sugar tax .

i know there have been a couple of advertising campaigns aimed at children in recent years , maybe they have n't had the desired effect , but i think that encouraging people to live a more active lifestyle in general is the best thing to do .
sugar is an issue though , no matter how you look at it , it 's not rare for british children to have several decayed teeth pulled out at an early age now so something has to be done .

documents.title: a view from someone who has 'been obese most of their life '
text: chris , 58 from gloucestershire the government has a responsibility to its citizens but not to the point of controlling what we eat .
it 's our choice : we have to accept the consequences of our actions and not rely on the state to tell us what to do .
advertising is everywhere and it has been for the past 100 years .
so , every time we see an advert for coca cola , do we go out and buy one ?
it 's our choice ultimately .
i have lost seven stone since september 2015 through mindful eating .
i know what i eat , how many calories i am consuming , and how much sugar i digest .
we have to think about what we eat and why and ultimately learn self-control .

documents.title: lessons from elsewhere when it comes to a sugar tax
text: i asked readers below the line whether they felt any other countries had succeeded with levying products .
here 's the response i got .
lolexplosm 18 august 2016 1:28pm debatable .
have any food taxes been proven to have caused any significant improvement in public health ?
the danish tried a fat tax , it was scrapped a year or two later as i think people simply went across or ordered from the borders and stocked up .
i could be wrong but i do n't think it did their economy any favours either .

mexico , although probably not a fair comparison with the u.k. , appeared to have some success in reducing consumption but this seems to be creeping back up and does n't appear to significantly be altering calorie intake .
the end result will be calls for more taxes and higher rates .
would love to hear more on this in the comments .

documents.title: tackling childhood obesity : the power of pokemon go
text: a view from doctor mahiben maruthappu , co-founder of revere care and advisor to the nhs , submitted through our form .
my thoughts on what we could do to prevent child obesity .
like a blast from the past , pokemon go has swept smartphone users off their couches , across streets , hunting for virtual creatures night and day .
at first glance it seems illogical .
but the success of pokemon go is a great illustrator of what technology can do to help people stay fit and get healthy - across all ages .

a few years ago , wearable pedometers were launched by fitbit and jawbone , allowing not only serious athletes , but also those suffering from illness and health problems to measure their efforts , from time spent walking or running , to steps taken and calories burnt.it was even suggested that these gadgets encouraged people to exercise more .

documents.title: the sugar tax is voluntary , not compulsory - which weakens it
text: views on government plans from our health editor sarah boseley : the tax on sugary soft drinks is , of course , welcomed by health experts , although it does not come in for two more years .
reformulation of products to reduce sugar by 20 % is a sound aspiration , but as with the responsibility deal '' the cameron government made with the food industry , it is voluntary .
ironically , says prof graham mcgregor , the cardiologist who heads action on sugar , the industry wanted mandatory reformulation , to remove any competitive disadvantage .

documents.title: view from a former teacher
text: we 've got some thoughts in via our form from a retired primary teacher .

matilda , north wales said : when it was announced that school meals had to be healthier , the school cook in my school noticed that reception children ate the pasta/rice based meals she introduced whereas older children turned up their noses - in other words , start as young as possible to introduce healthy food ( which of course many nurseries do ) .
stop free school meals to all in england , i think studies have showed it does n't do anything for obesity regulation and the money could be better targeted .

documents.title: will the sugar tax hit the poorest hardest ?
text: it 's a point that 's been raised a few times below the line .
id17071882 18 august 2016 12:46pm people will still buy that mars bar at 11am for a snack if it costs 90p instead of 80p .
the difference the sugar tax will make is that those who are already struggling financially will now struggle even more .
when the time comes to pay the rent or pay a utility bill it will be even harder , and the risk of falling into debt more likely .

documents.title: a sugar tax : for and against
text: for tenthred 18 august 2016 12:21pm concentrated extrinsic sugars are a poison .
ideally they should be banned , but realistically i think there should be a sugar tax on all concentrated sugars , on fructose and 'modified maize ' and not just on 'sugar ' itself .
and not just in drinks , in everything .

sugar is particularly pernicious , imo , where it is put into savoury foods to improve what producers call 'mouth feel ' and then often accompanied by loads of extra salt to counteract the sweetness .
because it is n't just that sugar makes you fat and rots your teeth and makes you crave more sugar , it also messes up your metabolism and can lead to type2 diabetes even if you do n't overeat .
against nicola lane 18 august 2016 12:23pm so what are manufacturers supposed to put into foods ?
they are being told to take out everything that makes food taste good - fat , salt and now sugar .
in addition for the past 40ish years we have been telling them that fat is the demon , use as much sugar as you like just make everything low fat .
now we are saying take the sugar out too .
they could use sweetners , but apparently they cause ( insert long list of diseases/conditions ) .
oh , and they have to make everything affordable and shelf stable for a month .
manufacturers ca n't change the formulation of foods overnight - well not and hope to actually sell any of it !
the obesity problem is n't down to sugary drinks - it is down to modern lifestyles and a sugar tax will simply make the weekly shop more expensive it simply wo n't address the real causes .

documents.title: it 's not a sugar issue , it 's a fructose issue
text: noiseformind 18 august 2016 12:19pm after robert lustig presentation it should have been game over for fructose .
the debate issues start precisely with call it a `` sugar '' problem .
its not a `` sugar '' issue .
its a fructose issue .
fructose gets metabolized in the liver just like alcohol does .
no one would drink 90 pounds of alcohol yet people eat 90 pounds of sugar with no warning label in the containers .
fructose should be as tight regulated as alcohol and that 's it .
everytime someone stops eating sugar the liver responds by getting well .
even before i started lchf and intermittent fasting i quit on sugar .
the results : my alt and ast enzymes went from over 100 to 11 and 12 , respectively .
body fat does n't come from dietary fat : body fat comes from dietary sugar .

documents.title: what should we be focusing on to tackle childhood obesity ?
text: some interesting views on the real reasons for our obesity crisis and how to solve it .
bob57575 18 august 2016 12:12pm education .
the parents are probably a write-off , but get it into the next generation 's heads that driving everywhere , eating shit food and guzzing sugary drinks leads to serious health problems .
do n't just say 'oh , you could die a few years younger ' .
show them the chronic illnesses , the heart attack and stroke victims and such .
i 'd argue it worked for smoking ( but then that was obviously combined with escalating taxes on ciggies ) .
lourdepaul 18 august 2016 12:09pm no , parental responsibility is still required , and still ignored by the kinds of people who think legislation should be the panacea for all societal ills .
i think we 're getting worse because of this attitude of asking government to take control of our decisions .
they 're children - parents decide what they eat , not the children themselves .
i have zero respect for anyone whining otherwise like saying no to your kids is a hardship .
id5339723 18 august 2016 12:06pm just not good enough .
so much more to do and quickly - the incidence of obesity in general , never mind childhood , is indeed a national disgrace .
there should be limits on % of sugar in foods .
there is too much .
could be brought down gradually so we become accustomed to it .
all this feet dragging , though , as with everything , is excruciating .

documents.title: welcome to the debate
text: the government has announced its plans to tackle childhood obesity , and some people are less than impressed .
medical experts and campaigners criticised the strategy - centred on the sugar tax - as weak and embarrassing '' .
the strategy relies on voluntary action by the food and drink industry , which has undertaken to reduce by 20 % the amount of sugar in products such as cereals , desserts , yoghurts and sweets .
it 's been made clear to manufacturers that reducing sugar in their products means they will escape the sugar tax , not due to come in for two years .
so , what do you think of these plans ?
the money the government make from it will go to fund breakfast clubs and sport ( giving students an extra 30 minutes a day of physical activity ) .

alex renton wrote about the benefits of a sugar tax in march , saying : hundreds of millions will flow ( if osborne keeps his promise ) into children 's sports , neatly answering those who still believe , against the evidence , that the best way to address the excess calories modern children eat is through exercise . ''

however , critics complain that this should go hand in hand with other measures proposed by public health england : banning price-cutting promotions of junk food in supermarkets and restricting advertising of unhealthy food .
lipinski/pa what 's more , others feel that the sugar tax in its current form is an ineffective measure .

the british medical association said : although the government proposes targets for food companies to reduce the level of sugar in their products , the fact that these are voluntary and not backed up by regulation , renders them pointless .
targets are also needed to reduce levels of saturated fat and salt in products - these must be backed up by regulation . ''
the british soft drinks association is also unhappy the sugary drinks levy is going ahead .

given the economic uncertainty our country now faces , we 're disappointed the government wishes to proceed with a measure which analysis suggests will cause thousands of job losses and yet fail to have a meaningful impact on levels of obesity , '' said gavin partington , its director general .
he added that manufacturers were already cutting the sugar content of their drinks .
what do you think ?
